docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Medical Liability Reform'' (letter, July 2), Dr. Donald J. Palmisano, former president of the American Medical Association, refers to ''tidbits'' cited by Bob Herbert in a column last month that criticized the position of the A.M.A. and the insurance industry on the malpractice insurance ''crisis.''
docs.abstract: David S Casey Jr letter disputes Dr Donald J Palmisano July 2 letter opposing recent Bob Herbert column criticizing position of American Medical Assn and insurance industry on malpractice insurance crisis

docs.lead_paragraph: Will actual policy issues play any role in this election? Not if the White House can help it. But if some policy substance does manage to be heard over the clanging of conveniently timed terror alerts, voters will realize that they face some stark choices. Here's one of them: tax cuts for the very well-off versus health insurance. John Kerry has proposed an ambitious health care plan that would extend coverage to tens of millions of uninsured Americans, while reducing premiums for the insured. To pay for that plan, Mr. Kerry wants to rescind recent tax cuts for the roughly 3 percent of the population with incomes above $200,000.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column examines Sen John Kerry's health care plan; says Kerry would extend coverage to tens of millions of uninsured Americans, while reducing premiums for insured, and would pay for plan by rescinding recent tax cuts for about 3 percent of population with incomes above $200,000; says Kerry claims his plan would cost $653 billion over decade, and nonpartisan Tax Policy Center estimates that revenue gain from his tax plan would be $631 billion over decade; says there are some objections to Kerry plan, but it would certainly help far more people than it would hurt; says Pres Bush could never win any clear national debate about health care and taxes (M)
docs.snippet: Will actual policy issues play any role in this election? Not if the White House can help it. But if some policy substance does manage to be heard over the clanging of conveniently timed terror alerts, voters will realize that they face some stark...

docs.lead_paragraph: India's new government presented a budget Thursday that was clearly focused on the poor and rural populations, but which also raises taxes in an attempt to rein in the swelling budget deficit. ''Our economic strategy is to empower the people, especially the poor, with access to education and health,'' Palaniappan Chidambaram, the finance minister, said in an address to Parliament on Thursday. ''This will reinforce the growth process.''

headline.main: India Budget Raises Taxes to Finance Aid to Poor

docs.abstract: India's new government presents budget that focuses on poor and rural populations, but also raises taxes in attempt to rein in swelling budget deficit; Finance Min Palaniappan Chidambaram allocates $2.22 billion to provide safe drinking water, basic education, health care and infrastructure to India's villages; plan imposes 2 percent surcharge on taxes to raise cash for education initiative; also dispenses with long-term capital gains tax on stocks and bonds, and replaces it with 0.15 percent tax on securities transactions; raises limits on foreign investment in several areas; photo (M)
docs.snippet: India's new government presented a budget Thursday that was clearly focused on the poor and rural populations, but which also raises taxes in an attempt to rein in the swelling budget deficit.    ''Our economic strategy is to empower the people,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert McDonald, the former deputy Nassau County executive under the administration of Thomas S. Gulotta, was sentenced on Thursday in federal court to one year and one day in prison for his involvement in a health insurance scandal that prosecutors said cost the county $70 million. He was also ordered to pay back the county $150,000 he received in bribes. Mr. McDonald pleaded guilty to charges of bribery, money laundering and obstruction of justice. He sobbed and begged the court for forgiveness and mercy during his sentencing before Judge Joanna Seybert of United States District Court.

headline.main: Former Aide to County Leader Gets Prison in Insurance Case

docs.abstract: Robert McDonald, former deputy Nassau County executive under administration of Thomas S Gulotta, is sentenced to one year and one day in prison for his involvement in county workers' health insurance scandal that cost county $70 million; is also ordered to repay bribes of $150,000 he received; is given lighter sentence because of his wife's illness and for cooperating with federal prosecutors that led to convictions of dozen of others involved in crime (S)
docs.snippet: Robert McDonald, the former deputy Nassau County executive under the administration of Thomas S. Gulotta, was sentenced on Thursday in federal court to one year and one day in prison for his involvement in a health insurance scandal that prosecutors...

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the large health insurer, said yesterday that a Congressional panel had approved a $740 million tax refund related to losses on businesses the company sold in the 1990's. The refund will be recorded as income from discontinued operations in the third quarter, said Aetna, which is based in Hartford. The ruling by the United States Joint Committee on Taxation completes an Internal Revenue Service audit of Aetna's tax returns from 1991 through 2001, the company said. The refund relates primarily to losses on the sale of Aetna's reinsurance unit to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company in 1992 and the sale of the company's property and casualty business in 1996 to Travelers Group, now part of St. Paul Travelers Companies, an Aetna spokesman, Roy Clason, said.

headline.main: U.S. PANEL APPROVES A $740 MILLION TAX REFUND TO AETNA

docs.abstract: Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation approves $740 million tax refund for Aetna related to losses on businesses it sold in 1990's, primarily reinsurance unit sold to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co and property and casualty business sold to Travelers Group, now St Paul Travelers Cos (S)
docs.snippet: Aetna, the large health insurer, said yesterday that a Congressional panel had approved a $740 million tax refund related to losses on businesses the company sold in the 1990's. The refund will be recorded as income from discontinued operations in...

docs.lead_paragraph: In picking Senator John Edwards as his running mate, Senator John Kerry signaled that he would renew emphasis on economic anxieties and try to refute President Bush's assertion that good times have returned. Although Mr. Kerry's attack was blunted by a surge in job creation from March through May, his theme of a ''middle-class squeeze'' and Mr. Edwards's theme of ''two Americas'' may resonate with underlying economic conditions.

headline.main: Revived Focus on Anxiety Over Economic Conditions

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry's choice of Sen John Edwards as running mate signals that he will renew emphasis on economic anxieties and try to refute Pres Bush's assertions that good times have returned; Kerry's theme of 'middle-class squeeze' and Edwards's theme of 'two Americas' may resonate with underlying economic conditions; particularly ominous indicator for Bush is apparently high number of people who have stopped looking for work and dropped out of labor force; unlike other recoveries, workers are not surging back to job market this time (M)
docs.snippet: In picking Senator John Edwards as his running mate, Senator John Kerry signaled that he would renew emphasis on economic anxieties and try to refute President Bush's assertion that good times have returned.    Although Mr. Kerry's attack was blunted...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Falluja Withdrawal Created Terror Haven, Officials Say American and Iraqi officials say that a decision in April to pull back American forces from Falluja inadvertently created a safe haven for terrorists and insurgents there. But officials are reluctant to send American troops back into the city for fear of touching off another uprising. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional investigators said Wednesday that 15,000 children with psychiatric disorders were improperly incarcerated last year because no mental health services were available. The figures were compiled by the Democratic staff of the House Committee on Government Reform in the first such nationwide survey of juvenile detention centers.

headline.main: Many Youths Reported Held Awaiting Mental Help

docs.abstract: Nationwide survey of juvenile detention centers shows that 15,000 children with psychiatric disorders were improperly incarcerated last year because no mental health services were available; findings are presented at Senate hearing; detention centers responding to survey said youths with mental disorders are locked up because there is no other place for them to go while awaiting treatment, and most said they are holding mentally ill youngsters with no pending charges (M)
docs.snippet: Congressional investigators said Wednesday that 15,000 children with psychiatric disorders were improperly incarcerated last year because no mental health services were available.    The figures were compiled by the Democratic staff of the House...

docs.lead_paragraph: With drug prices skyrocketing, the pharmaceutical industry has long had plenty of critics. And in a measure of just how badly tarnished the industry's image has become, even some of its most prominent defenders are turning against it. That could spell trouble, which is why the drug industry is about to begin a charm offensive to try to win back the nation's affection.

headline.main: Drug Makers Seek to Mend Their Fractured Image

docs.abstract: US drug makers are trying to fix industry's tarnished image; Merck & Co's former chairman Roy Vagelos, who was one of industry's most prominent boosters, now condemns drug makers for 'exorbitant' prices of new medicines and 'galloping' annual increases of old ones; predicts government price controls are almost inevitable; Pfizer holds news conference to announce effort to provide discounted drugs to working poor and anyone without health insurance; drug companies are concerned that Congress will pass legislation that would legalize drug imports or allow government officials to bargain for discounts, either of which could put big dent in industry's profits and investments; photos (M)
docs.snippet: With drug prices skyrocketing, the pharmaceutical industry has long had plenty of critics. And in a measure of just how badly tarnished the industry's image has become, even some of its most prominent defenders are turning against it.     That could...

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are no easy answers in reforming health care, but some economists in the field increasingly believe there may indeed be viable solutions to at least some of the nation's health problems. The seemingly intractable issues are well known. Americans spend some 14 percent of gross domestic product on health care, while other advanced nations spend an average of 8 percent. In the United States, the proportion may rise to 18 percent by 2013.

headline.main: Economic Scene; Some new studies look at what to do about the troubled American health care system.

docs.abstract: Jeff Madrick Economic Scene column on new studies on troubled American health care system; cites findings of studies by Uwe E Reinhardt of Princeton and Peter S Hussey and Gerard F Anderson of Johns Hopkins and David M Cutler, health care economist at Harvard, among professional economists in book Your Money or Your Life; photo (M)
